docs.lead_paragraph: BABY BOOMERS are aging but not gracefully. Refusing to give in to wrinkles, sags and spreading middles, both men and women are seeking cosmetic surgery in record numbers. Westchester reflects the national trend -- in the last five years, the number of people seeking the most popular form of cosmetic surgery, liposuction, more than tripled, while the number of women undergoing breast enlargements recorded a fourfold increase. Doctors here who perform cosmetic surgery say rising numbers of residents are seeking to be more youthful and more attractive by being tucked, scraped, stapled and suctioned.

headline.main: In the Footsteps Of Ponce de Leon

docs.abstract: Baby boomers are aging, but not gracefully; refusing to give in to wrinkles, sags and spreading middles, both men and women are seeking cosmetic surgery in record numbers; Westchester reflects national trend--in last five years, number of people seeking most popular form of cosmetic surgery, liposuction, more than tripled, while number of women undergoing breast enlargement recorded four-fold increase (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Like two-thirds of the nation's governors, Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey is now wrestling with the ''problem'' of fat budget surpluses brought on by a booming economy. This month, to no one's great surprise, Mrs. Whitman proposed in her State of the State Message to send money back to taxpayers in the form of a rebate for their local property taxes. The proposal is certain to be popular, but there is a worrisome catch. The cost of the rebate would grow from $200 million the first year to $1 billion annually in five years, raising questions about whether the money will be there to pay for it if the economy turns down. Mrs. Whitman's zest for tax-cutting is a signature of her career and crucial to her claim for consideration as a nominee for Vice President in the next national election. She first ran in 1993 on a pledge to cut the income tax, and then kept her word by using budget gimmicks to make up for the lost revenues. Her past tax cuts now amount to about $1.2 billion in annual lost revenue. Currently she proposes to cut taxes in the next five years by nearly as much as in the last five. But since Mrs. Whitman cannot run for a third term, it will probably be up to her successor to deal with any adverse long-term consequences of her actions. That should give pause to the State Legislature.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Gov Christine Tood Whitman's proposal to give New Jersey taxpayers rebate for their local property taxes raises troubling question of whether money will be there for rebate in coming years if economy turns down (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Administrators of Nassau County's health care plan said today that its severe cost overruns were caused by poor financial decisions by county officials, dismissing the officials' assertions that company mismanagement and kickbacks were to blame. James M. Pennington, chief executive officer of Benefit Plan Administrators, of Melville, bristled at the accusations that his company had overcharged the county, received kickbacks from its health care subcontractors, and billed for services that were never delivered.

headline.main: Nassau County Called at Fault For Overruns In Health Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: Many of the poorest among the nation's 39 million Medicare beneficiaries, people with incomes below $10,000 a year, are going without aid from government safety net programs that are intended to help them pay their health care expenses. The biggest, most generous of the programs covers doctor and hospital care that Medicare does not cover, typically 20 percent to 30 percent of the elderly's health care expenses. It also exempts its enrollees from paying Medicare's $45.50 monthly premium for doctors' office visits, deducted from Social Security checks. Two other programs exempt Medicare recipients with slightly higher incomes from paying the premium.

headline.main: Medicare Safety Nets Fail To Catch Many of the Poor

docs.abstract: Many of poorest among nation's 39 million Medicare beneficiaries are going without aid from government safety net programs that are intended to help them pay their health care expenses; figures are in studies by Families USA, consumer advocacy group, as well as Urban Institute and several research philanthropies; Clinton Administration does not dispute studies, which attribute low enrollments to conflicts between Federal and state agencies as well as dearth of program leadership and coordination, labyrinthine red tpe and demeaning application procedures (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Central Bank of Brazil Acts to Stabilize Currency Faced with another steep decline in the value of its currency, Brazil's central bank used more of its dwindling reserves of dollars to buy Brazilian money in the foreign exchange market. The bank's action helped stabilize the value of the currency, the real. But it did little to calm the nerves of financial analysts and economists on edge over the country's future. The main stock market index, the Bovespa, declined fell 1.79 percent, to 7,190.21, its second consecutive drop. [Page C2.] Internet Fever Starts to Cool Down Internet fever has been growing as shares of newly public companies have soared. But this week, a bit of the air leaked out of what many Wall Street pros call the Internet bubble and many analysts are warning of a steep decline that could rattle the wider market. [A1.] Boeing Settles Discrimination Suit As expected, Boeing announced a proposed $15 million settlement to a racial discrimination suit brought by hundreds of its workers in the Seattle and Philadelphia areas who contended that discrimination and retaliation were common at Boeing plants. [C3.] Dustin Hoffman Wins Magazine Suit A judge has ordered Los Angeles magazine to pay $1.5 million in actual damages to the actor Dustin Hoffman for publishing a computer-altered image of him in an evening dress and high heels. The magazine had used Mr. Hoffman's head, taken from a still from the 1982 movie ''Tootsie,'' and placed it on a body wearing a Richard Tyler designer dress and Ralph Lauren shoes. [A20.] Caldor Set to Close Its 145 Stores The discount retail chain Caldor, which filed for bankruptcy protection more than three years ago, has decided to close its 145 stores in nine East Coast states and dismiss its 20,000 employees. The retailer said it was liquidating because it was unable to negotiate a reorganization plan with creditors. [B5.] Higher Health Premiums Proposed Medicare beneficiaries with relatively high incomes would have to pay higher premiums under proposals outlined by the chairman of a Congressional commission seeking ways to avert a financial crisis in the health insurance program for the elderly. [A16.] Many of the poorest among the nation's 39 million Medicare beneficiaries, people with incomes below $10,000 a year, are going without aid from Government safety net programs intended to help them pay their health care expenses. [A9.] Intel's Market Share Declines Intel's share of the microprocessor market fell to 75.7 percent from 87.1 percent in the fourth quarter as its rival, Advanced Micro Devices, stole business, a research firm said. [C14.] DaimlerChrysler Talks With Nissan The two chairmen of DaimlerChrysler held ''constructive discussions'' with the president of Nissan Motor, Yoshikazu Hanawa, about its truck affiliate, but did not disclose any details. The Japanese auto maker, with $20 billion in debt, has recently put part of itself up for sale. DaimlerChrysler had already been holding talks with Nissan Motor about its Nissan Diesel division. [C2.] Siemens Net Income Rises 12% Higher sales in Europe sent net income for German electronics company Siemens up 12 percent in the fiscal first quarter. [C2.] Bankers Trust to Pay Bonus Bankers Trust, which Germany's Deutsche Bank is about to acquire, has agreed to pay employees about $1.1 billion in bonuses for 1998, when it lost $6 million. The bonuses, to be awarded this month, include cash, stock and partnership shares. [C14.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Higher-income Medicare beneficiaries would have to pay higher premiums under proposals outlined today by Senator John B. Breaux, the chairman of a bipartisan commission seeking ways to avert a financial crisis in the health insurance program for the elderly. In his State of the Union Message on Tuesday, President Clinton proposed using some of the Federal budget surplus for Medicare. Mr. Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat, said that would help shore up Medicare but would not solve its long-term financial problems and did not reduce the need for radical changes in the program.
docs.abstract: Higher-income Medicare beneficiaries would pay higher premiums under proposal outlined by Sen John B Breaux, chairman of bipartisan commission seeking ways to avert financial crisis in health insurance program for elderly; Breaux says Pres Clinton's proposal to use some of Federal budget surplus for Medicare would not solve its long-term financial problems or reduce need for radical changes in program; 17-member commission will submit its recommendations to Pres Clinton and Congress by Mar 1 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Salinas Is Convicted In 1994 Assassination Raul Salinas de Gortari, the brother of Mexico's former President, was convicted of ordering the 1994 assassination of a prominent politician and sentenced to 50 years in prison. The verdict shattered the impunity that shielded powerful Mexicans for decades. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of the presentation today by Dale Bumpers, former Democratic Senator from Arkansas, in the Senate impeachment trial of the President. (Today's excerpt and transcripts were recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.) Mr. Chief Justice, distinguished House managers from the House of Representatives, colleagues. I have seen the look of disappointment on many faces, because I know a lot of people thought you were rid of me once and for all. And I've taken a lot of ribbing this afternoon. But I have seriously negotiated with some people, particularly on this side, by an offer to walk out and not deliver this speech in exchange for a few votes. I understand three have it under active consideration.

headline.main: Weight of History Is 'on All of Us,' Senate Is Told by One of Its Own

docs.lead_paragraph: A bitter dispute has broken out within the Clinton Administration over the legal rights of Medicare beneficiaries, with some officials trying to limit those rights even as President Clinton urges Congress to establish new protections for millions of other patients with private health insurance. At issue are Federal court rulings that upheld the rights of six million Medicare beneficiaries in health maintenance organizations.

headline.main: Rulings on Medicare Rights Split White House

docs.abstract: Bitter dispute breaks out within Clinton Administration over legal rights of Medicare beneficiaries, with some officials trying to limit such rights even as Pres Clinton urges Congress to establish new protections for other patients with private insurance; at issue are Federal court rulings upholding right of six million Medicare beneficiaries in HMOs; Medicare officials want Sec Donna Shalala to appeal to Supreme Court, but others in Administration say appeal would look ridiculous and outrage consumer groups and Congressional Democrats (S)
